properties.entry: Brightness of a qubit state depending on its length?
A measurement is not reversible! (Register will be re-initialized)
The y-register is too small to store all function values!

1. Structure of the work space window

On the left, you find the control panel, in which there are the buttons to initialize and to control the run of the quantum program. The upper horizontal panel consists of buttons to add quantum gates to the circuit canvas directly below it. At the bottom you find the representation of the quantum register. It is divided into a part which receives the input and supplies the output, called the x-register, and into a part called y-register, which serves mainly as a temporary qubit storage, as e.g. for Shor's function evaluation principle.


2. Initializing the quantum register

To determine the size of the register, first click on the button ψ0. A qubit register of size n is determined by 2n base states. In the register panel, each basis state is represented as a single square whose color specifies the (complex) amplitude of the base state, cf. the documentation.


3. Designing the quantum circuit

Having initialized the quantum register, you can add several quantum gates to the circuit by simply clicking on the buttons in the circuit design panel. Usually you are prompted for further necessary information. The currently last added gate can be deleted by using the button on the right-most position.


4. Running the algorithm

You can run the algorithm in two modes. Either you can go stepwise by clicking the two \"blocked\" arrow buttons in the control panel, or you can perform a single run by clicking the green arrow lower-most.
does not contain a format representing a quantum circuit!

If you are trying to load a file created by an older version
of the jQuantum simulator prior to 1.1, please convert it
with the conversion program available under

http://jQuantum.sourceforge.net/converter.jar

Color Map of the Complex Plane

A complex number z can be represented uniquely by a pair of real numbers. Usually, there are used two different representations, the Cartesian representation as the sum

z = x + iy

of its real part x and its imaginary part y, or the polar decomposition

z = r eiφ

as the product of the absolute value (or the length) r = |z| of z and the phase (or the argument) φ of z.

The polar decomposition is the basis for the color map of the complex plane. Here, the hue, as a combination of color and brightness, of a complex number z is given by its phase φ and its absolute value |z|. The color of the origin z = 0 remains undetermined, however since its absolute value is 0, its hue is black.

For instance, a positive real number is red, whereas a negative real number is light blue.
